title: Syllabus
text:
Instructor: Ed Hagen
Email: edhagen@wsu.edu
Office hours: Anytime. Email for Zoom appointment 
Lecture hall: VMMC 219 and live over Zoom
Days and times: MW 10:35-11:50
Semester: Fall 2025
Credits: 3

title: Syllabus
text:
Course description
This course introduces an evolutionary biological approach to human psychology and behavior. Topics that will be explored include the modern synthesis, human sexuality, male-female relations, cooperation, violence, parent-child relations, mental illnesses, and cultural transmission. For the complete list of topics, assignments, and grading, see below.

title: Syllabus
text:
Textbooks and readings

Evolutionary Psychology: The New Science of the Mind, latest edition. David Buss.
The Selfish Gene, 2nd edition or later. Richard Dawkins.
Selected readings available from the course web site.

title: Syllabus
text:
Grading
Students are responsible for all material in the lectures and the assigned portions of the texts. Grading will be on a curve, and will be based on three tests:

Two midterms (each with 25 multiple choice & true/false questions): 25% of grade each
Final (50 multiple choice & true/false questions): 50% of grade

You are responsible for assigned reading even when the material is not covered in lecture. The final exam is comprehensive (i.e., it covers material from the entire course).

title: Syllabus
text:
Assigned reading and test dates
EXAMS CANNOT BE RESCHEDULED ON AN INDIVIDUAL BASIS. MAKEUP EXAMS ONLY AVAILABLE FOR STUDENTS WITH A MEDICAL OR SIMILAR EXCUSE. DO NOT SCHEDULE TRIPS OR OTHERWISE PLAN TO BE ABSENT DURING THE MIDTERMS OR FINALS WEEK!

section: Week 12 (Nov 4): Darwinian medicine I: Drug use

title: Syllabus
section: Week 13 (Nov 11): Darwinian medicine II: Depression and suicide
text:
Week 13 (Nov 11): Darwinian medicine II: Depression and suicide

Buss: Ch. 3, Ch. 13 section on clinical psychology
Hagen 1999. The functions of postpartum depression (web site)
Hagen 2007. Gestures of despair and hope: A view on deliberate self-harm from economics and evolutionary biology (web site)

title: Syllabus
text:
Week 14 (Nov 18): The evolution of culture

Buss: Ch. 13 section on cultural psychology
Hagen and Hammerstein 2007. Did Neanderthals and other early humans sing? Seeking the biological roots of music in the territorial advertisements of primates, lions, hyenas, and wolves (web site)
Sugiyama 2001. Food, foragers and folklore: the role of narrative in human subsistence (web site)
Henrich and McElreath 2003. The evolution of cultural evolution (web site)
